conclusion: Determine the condition under which the plank starts to move upward by analyzing forces on the block and plank.
The block is at the lower right of the plank, with forces F1 and F2 applied.
Identify the forces acting on the block: weight, normal force, frictional force, horizontal force F1, and vertical force F2.
The maximum static frictional force is f_max = μN.
The block will start to move when net vertical force is zero or negative, and net horizontal force overcomes friction.
Set up equations for the block: N sin θ + F2 - mg = 0 and F1 - N cos θ = 0.
Determine angle θ using plank geometry: tan θ = sqrt(L^2 - x^2) / x.
Relate forces to motion: block moves when N sin θ + F2 - mg = 0 and F1 - N cos θ = 0.
Solve equations: F1 tan θ + F2 = mg and F1 = N cos θ.
Substitute N = F1 / cos θ into F2 equation: F2 = mg - (F1 / cos θ) sin θ.
Final condition for F1: F1 > mg cos θ / (sin θ + μ cos θ).
